description.en:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants. Look for signs of hunger, such as beginning to fuss, sucking fingers, or moving lips.
- Breastfeed day and night whenever your baby wants, at least 8 times in 24 hours. Frequent feeding produces more milk.
- Do not give other foods or fluids. Breast milk is all your baby needs.
description.sw:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants. Look for signs of hunger, such as beginning to fuss, sucking fingers, or moving lips.
- Breastfeed day and night whenever your baby wants, at least 8 times in 24 hours. Frequent feeding produces more milk.
- Do not give other foods or fluids. Breast milk is all your baby needs.

description.en:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give a variety of mashed or finely chopped family food, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
-Give 3/4 cup at each meal (1 cup = 250 ml).
- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals.
- Continue to feed your child slowly, patiently. Encourage - but do not force - your child to eat.
- For snacks, give small chewable items that the child can hold. Let your child try to eat the snack, but provide help if needed.

description.en:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give thick porridge or well mashed foods, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
- Start by giving 2 to 3 tablespoons of food. Gradually increase to 1/2 cups (1 cup = 250 ml). Give 2 to 3 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks each day between meals when the child seems hungry.

description.en:
- Give a variety of family foods to your child, including animal source foods and vitamin rich fruits and vegetables.
- Give at least 1 full cup (250 ml) at each meal.
- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals.
- If your child refuses a new food, offer "tastes" several times. Show that you like the food.
Be patient.
- Talk with your child during a meal, and keep eye contact.

description.sw:
Diagnosed if ONE OR MORE of the following criteria:
- Age 2-59 months: Weight-for-height z-score less than -3
- Age 6-59 months: MUAC less than 115mm
- Age 2-5 months: Weight-for-age z-score less than -3

AND EITHER:
- Complication of malnutrition (Danger sign, SpO2 less than 90%, hypoglycaemia, any severe infection diagnosis, severe anaemia, chest indrawing pneumonia, measles, chicken pox) OR
- None of the above complications and FAIL appetite test (or appetite test not available and mother reports poor appetite)

Malnutrition develops when a child’s diet lacks amounts of essential vitamins, minerals and other nutrients. Illness and disease can often cause malnutrition. Children with severe malnutrition have an increased risk of severe illness and death. Identifying children with malnutrition and treating them can help prevent many severe diseases and death.

description.en: ANTIBIOTIC: normal dose for infection
Antibiotic: 7mg/Kg/day, max 400mg/day

Antibiotic for non CNS infections
Dosage: 50mg/kg/day max 2g/day

Refer urgently with caretaker for inpatient management at a health centre or hospital with sufficient capacity to manage the illness of the patient. If referral is not possible, manage the child as described in the national guidelines or WHO Pocket Book for hospital care for children.

description.en:
"If the child is able to breastfeed:
Ask the mother to breastfeed the child.
If the child is not able to breastfeed but is able to swallow:
Give expressed breast milk or a breast-milk substitute.
If neither of these is available, give sugar water*.
Give 30 - 50 ml of milk or sugar water* before departure.
If the child is not able to swallow:
Give 50 ml of milk or sugar water* by nasogastric tube.
If no nasogastric tube available, give 1 teaspoon of sugar moistened with 1-2 drops of water sublingually and repeat doses every 20 minutes to prevent relapse.
* To make sugar water: Dissolve 4 level teaspoons of sugar (20 grams) in a 200-ml cup of clean water. (IMCI 2014)"

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis - any one of the following:
- Age 2 - 59 months and weight for height z-score -2  to -3 
- Age 6 - 59 months and MUAC from 115mm to 124mm 
- Age 2 - 5 months and weight for age z-score <-2 to -3 

Malnutrition develops when a child’s diet lacks amounts of essential vitamins, minerals and other nutrients. Illness and disease can often cause malnutrition. Children with moderate malnutrition have an increased risk of severe illness and death. Identifying children with malnutrition and treating them can help prevent many severe diseases and death.

description.en:
ASK - How are you feeding your child?

If the child is receiving any breast milk, ASK:
- How many times during the day?
- Do you also breastfeed during the night?
- Does the child take any other food or fluids?

What food or fluids?
- How many times per day?
- What do you use to feed the child?

If MODERATE ACUTE MALNUTRITION or if a child with CONFIRMED HIV INFECTION fails to gain weight or loses weight between monthly measurements, ASK:
- How large are servings?
- Does the child receive his own serving?
- Who feeds the child and how?
- What foods are available in the home?
- During this illness, has the child's feeding changed?
If yes, how?

description.en:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants. Look for signs of hunger, such as beginning to fuss, sucking fingers, or moving lips.
- Breastfeed day and night whenever your baby wants, at least 8 times in 24 hours. Frequent feeding produces more milk.
- Do not give other foods or fluids. Breast milk is all your baby needs.
description.sw:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants. Look for signs of hunger, such as beginning to fuss, sucking fingers, or moving lips.
- Breastfeed day and night whenever your baby wants, at least 8 times in 24 hours. Frequent feeding produces more milk.
- Do not give other foods or fluids. Breast milk is all your baby needs.

description.en:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give thick porridge or well mashed foods, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
- Start by giving 2 to 3 tablespoons of food. Gradually increase to 1/2 cups (1 cup = 250 ml). Give 2 to 3 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks each day between meals when the child seems hungry.

description.en:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give a variety of mashed or finely chopped family food, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
-Give 1/2 cup at each meal(1 cup = 250 ml).
- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals. The child will eat if hungry.
- For snacks, give small chewable items that the child can hold. Let your child try to eat the snack, but provide help if needed.

description.en:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give a variety of mashed or finely chopped family food, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
-Give 3/4 cup at each meal (1 cup = 250 ml).
- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals.
- Continue to feed your child slowly, patiently. Encourage - but do not force - your child to eat.
- For snacks, give small chewable items that the child can hold. Let your child try to eat the snack, but provide help if needed.

description.en:
- Give a variety of family foods to your child, including animal source foods and vitamin rich fruits and vegetables.
- Give at least 1 full cup (250 ml) at each meal.
- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals.
- If your child refuses a new food, offer "tastes" several times. Show that you like the food.
Be patient.
- Talk with your child during a meal, and keep eye contact.

description.en:
Return for follow-up in 30 days to re-assess moderate malnutrition, review feeding and weight gain.

If trouble with feeding evaluate follow-up for in 7 days.

description.en: Proceed with investigations / assessment for tuberculosis screening as defined by your health facility protocols.
description.sw: Proceed with investigations / assessment for tuberculosis screening as defined by your health facility protocols.

description.en:
- Children with moderate to severe malnutrition, significant hemoptysis, significant loss of weight, cough or fever >=2 weeks, known close TB contact in past 12 months with respiratory complaints, should be evaluated for TB infection
-	Refer for TB assessment or if TB assessment performed at this health facility, follow in-house protocol. 
-	If patient is stable, do not give antibiotics until specimen collection is completed

description.en:
Diaper rash is usually caused by wetness and friction. Urine and stool can cause even more irritation, and this leads to breakdown of the skin. Some products used to clean the skin can sometimes add the irritation. 
Once the skin under the diaper becomes irritated, germs like bacteria and yeast (like Candida) can infect the skin and worsen the rash. 
REF Society for Pediatric Dermatolgy 2018

description.en: Apply on affected area every 6 hours until the rash disappears, then continue for another 7 days.

No inpatient referral is needed.
The patient may however need an outpatient referral for another diagnosis.

Advise the caretaker to bring back the child if the child presents: 
- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)
- Cough duration more than 2 weeks
- Neck mass persisting more than 4 weeks

*Consider scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

(adapted from IMCI 2014, based on studies from Kallander et al. PLoS Med, 2018; and Mullany et al. PLoS Med, 2018)

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis - Head trauma and ONE OR MORE OF THE FOLLOWING:
- Danger sign
- Open skull fractur
- Altered mental status OR signs basilar skull fracture (checked if history of loss of consciousness OR severe headache OR major trauma OR vomiting)
description.sw: The child has had a serious head injury and must be referred or admitted to the hospital for surveillance and management.

description.en: Refer urgently with caretaker for inpatient management at a health centre or hospital with sufficient capacity to manage the illness of the patient. If referral is not possible, manage the child as described in the national guidelines or WHO Pocket Book for hospital care for children.

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis - head trauma and ALL of the following:
- NO open skull fracture 
- NO History of loss of consciousness 
- NO severe headache 
- NO major trauma 
- NO vomiting 
- NO Danger sign 
- NO altered mental status 
- NO signs basilar skull fracture

description.en:
The child may have a headache after head injury. 
Give them paracetamol every six hours if needed to relieve the pain
If the child develops cognitive fatigue (problems concentrating, difficulties with memory, more anxious, mood swings, changed sleep patterns, slowness when thinking), the child needs a complete rest for 24-48hrs (no watching TV or playing on mobile electronic devices).
Introduce gradually physical exercise (walking, cycling)
Avoid second trauma (preventing falls) 

Return to clinic if during the child's recovery (especially during the next 48hrs), he/she has any of the following:
- severe/persistent headache that is not relieved by paracetamol
- Frequent vomiting at home 
- Bleeding or discharge from the ear or nose
- A fit or convulsion 
- Difficulty in waking up or staying awake 

REF: Adapted from the Royal Children's Hospital Emergency, Neurosurgery and Neuropsychology departments' Head Injury fact sheets, 2018

description.en:
Keep the child for surveillance for 4 hours to see the progression of symptoms. If symptoms improve, the child may be okay to return home with head injury guidance. 

If symptoms worsen, referral to a referral/district hospital may be needed.

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis - ALL of the following: 
- Ear pain on one side (any age) or both sides (24 months of age or over)
- No ear discharge, no severe comorbidity (severe acute malnutrition, very low weight for age, sickle cell anaemia, HIV), no measles

Acute ear infection is a common condition in children and often occurs after a viral respiratory tract infection. The acute inflammation of the middle ear (acute otitis media, AOM) cause earache in older children and less specific symptoms in younger children (pulling or rubbing of the ear, fever, irritability, poor feeding). In most children, AOM resolves spontaneously within three days without antibiotic treatment.
description.sw: Acute ear infection is a common condition in children and often occurs after a viral respiratory tract infection. The acute inflammation of the middle ear (acute otitis media, AOM) cause earache in older children and less specific symptoms in younger children (pulling or rubbing of the ear, fever, irritability, poor feeding). In most children, AOM resolves spontaneously within three days without antibiotic treatment.

description.en:
The diagnosis of the patient does not require antibiotics because it is very likely not bacterial and/or often resolves without any medication. Antibiotics are not useful for viral infections, they are only useful for bacterial infections.

Giving an antibiotic for a viral illness or any illness not caused by bacteria is not good for the patient and may make the child more sick due to adverse effects of the antibiotics (diarrhea, rash, upset stomach). In the long run if children are exposed to antibiotics too many times when not needed, antibiotic resistance may develop. This means that antibiotics may not work when they are really needed. 
Reassure the patient and caretaker that antibiotics are not needed, and remind them of when to return to consultation if the child presents new symptoms, or does not get better.

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis - ALL of the following:
- Ear discharge for 14 days or more
- No hearing loss
- No suspicion of foreign object in ear

Chronic ear infection is characterized by continuing inflammation of the middle ear with discharge for more than 2 weeks. Hearing loss is an important complication and can lead to speech delay. Foreign bodies that have perforated the tympanic membrane or caused a lesion inside the ear can also cause chronic ear discharge.  If there are no signs of complication, oral antibiotics are not necessary.
description.sw: Chronic ear infection is characetrized by continuing inflammation of the middle ear with discharge for more than 2 weeks. Hearing loss is an important complication and can lead to speach delay. Foreign bodies that perorated the tympanic membrane or caused a lesion inside the ear can also cause chonic ear discharge.  If there are no signs of complication, oral antibiotics are not necessary.

description.en:
Dry the ear at least 3 times daily.
Roll clean absorbent cloth or soft, strong tissue paper into a wick.
Place the wick in the child's ear.
Remove the wick when wet.
Replace the wick with a clean one and repeat these steps until the ear is dry.
Do not put anything else in ear.
(Adapted from IMCI 2014)

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis - both of the following:
- Ear discharge for 14 days or more
- Hearing loss OR suspicion of foreign object in ear

Chronic ear infection is characterized by continuing inflammation of the middle ear with discharge for more than 2 weeks. Hearing loss is an important complication and can lead to speech delay. Foreign bodies that have perforated the tympanic membrane or caused a lesion inside the ear can also cause chronic ear discharge. Complicated chronic ear infections require oral antibiotics and review by a specialist

Chronic ear infection is characterized by continuing inflammation of the middle ear with discharge for more than 2 weeks. Hearing loss is an important complication and can lead to speech delay. description.en: Refer to health facility with expertise with ear problems including hearing loss, and extraction of foreign body in ear.
description.sw: Refer to health facility with expertise with ear problems including hearing loss, and extraction of foreign body in ear.

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis ONE OR MORE of the following:
- Ear discharge for less than 14 days
- Ear pain and severe comorbidity (severe acute malnutrition, very low weight for age, sickle cell anaemia, HIV), or measles
- Age under 24 months and ear pain on both sides

Acute ear infection is a common condition in children. The acute inflammation of the middle ear (acute otitis media, AOM) cause earache in older children and less specific symptoms in younger children (pulling or rubbing of the ear, fever, irritability, poor feeding). In most children, AOM resolves spontaneously within three days without antibiotic treatment. However, smaller children with bilateral AOM and children with a compromised immune system including those with severe comborbidity or with measles infection, need antibiotic treatment.
description.sw: Acute ear infection is a common condition in children. The acute inflammation of the middle ear (acute otitis media, AOM) cause earache in older children and less specific symptoms in younger children (pulling or rubbing of the ear, fever, irritability, poor feeding). In most children, AOM resolves spontaneously within three days without antibiotic treatment. However, smaller children with bilateral AOM and children with a compromised immune system including those with severe comborbidity or with measles infection, need antibiotic treatment.

description.en: ANTIBIOTIC: amoxicillin high dose (75-100mg/kg/day divided in 2 doses)

Dry the ear at least 3 times daily.
Roll clean absorbent cloth or soft, strong tissue paper into a wick.
Place the wick in the child's ear.
Remove the wick when wet.
Replace the wick with a clean one and repeat these steps until the ear is dry.
Do not put anything else in ear.
(Adapted from IMCI 2014)
description.sw:
Dry the ear at least 3 times daily.
Roll clean absorbent cloth or soft, strong tissue paper into a wick.
Place the wick in the child's ear.
Remove the wick when wet.
Replace the wick with a clean one and repeat these steps until the ear is dry.
Do not put anything else in ear.
(Adapted from IMCI 2014)

description.en:
"Eczema is a common, non-contagious skin infection that usually begins before the child is one year old. The affected skin is dry, red and itchy. Sometimes, these areas of skin can become cracked, weepy and then scab over. There is no cure for eczema, but there are many ways to keep eczema under control and help the child feel more comfortable. 
The severity of eczema can change over time. Secondary bacterial or viral skin infections may occur. 
The cause of eczema is not known, but if a familiy member has eczema, asthma or hay fever, it is more likely that the child will have eczema. Some children with eczema may also develop asthma or hay fever. Eczema can be triggered by overheating (clothing, heaters), irritation from soaps or detergents, food allergies, plant pollens, animal fur, viruses. 

REF: Royal Children's Hospital of Melbourne Fact sheets"

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis:
- Malaria test positive AND
- No danger signs, no signs of severe pneumonia, severe anaemia or jaundice, and oxygen saturation 90% or above.

Malaria is caused by parasites in the blood called plasmodia. These parasites are transmitted when an infected female anopheline mosquitoes bite humans.
In areas with very high malaria transmission, malaria is a major cause of death in children. A case of uncomplicated malaria can develop into severe malaria as soon as 24 hours after the fever first appears. Severe malaria is malaria with complications such as cerebral malaria, severe anaemia, or presence of any other general danger sign. The child can die if he or she does not receive urgent treatment.

"The child may be eating much less, or eating different foods during illness. Children often lose their appetite during illness. However, they should still be encouraged to eat the types of food recommended for their age, as often as recommended, even if they do not eat much. They should be offered their favourite nutritious foods, if possible, to encourage eating. Offer small feedings frequently. After illness, good feeding helps make up for any weight loss and prevent malnutrition.

During illness an infant or young child loses fluid due to fever, fast breathing, or diarrhoea. The child will feel better and stay stronger if he or she drinks extra fluid to prevent dehydration. Frequent breastfeeding will give the infant nourishment and help prevent dehydration. (IMCI Handbook)"

Criteria for diagnosis:
- Malaria test positive AND
- One or more danger sign, oxygen saturation below 90%, severe pneumonia, severe anaemia or jaundice

Malaria is caused by parasites in the blood called plasmodia. These parasites are transmitted when an infected female anopheline mosquitoes bite humans.
In areas with very high malaria transmission, malaria is a major cause of death in children. A case of uncomplicated malaria can develop into severe malaria as soon as 24 hours after the fever first appears. Severe malaria is malaria with complications such as cerebral malaria, severe anaemia, or presence of any other general danger sign. The child can die if he or she does not receive urgent treatment.

"If the child is able to breastfeed:
Ask the mother to breastfeed the child.
If the child is not able to breastfeed but is able to swallow:
Give expressed breast milk or a breast-milk substitute.
If neither of these is available, give sugar water*.
Give 30 - 50 ml of milk or sugar water* before departure.
If the child is not able to swallow:
Give 50 ml of milk or sugar water* by nasogastric tube.
If no nasogastric tube available, give 1 teaspoon of sugar moistened with 1-2 drops of water sublingually and repeat doses every 20 minutes to prevent relapse.
* To make sugar water: Dissolve 4 level teaspoons of sugar (20 grams) in a 200-ml cup of clean water. (IMCI 2014)"

description.en:
Diagnostic criteria ALL OF THE FOLLOWING:
- Generalised or localised skin problem
- Urticarial rash seen
- No danger signs
- No respiratory distress
- No signs of anaphylaxis

Urticaria (hives) are slightly raised, flesh coloured patches of the skin. They occur in groups on any part of the body and can look like mosquito bites. They are often very itchy. Hives are very common and usually caused by an allergic reaction, by chemicals in foods, medicines and plants or by a viral infection. This leads to a release of a chemical called histamine. Often, urticaria is caused by multiple triggers rather than one single cause. Often, a specific cause is not identified. The single patches last around 24 hours or less before fading without a trace. They can reappear at other sites of the body, but should resolve completely within 6 weeks. 
REF Royal Children's Hospital Melbourne fact sheets

description.en:
Diagnostic criteria:
- Urticarial rash AND ONE OR MORE OF THE FOLLOWING:
- Danger sign
- Respiratory distress
- 'Anaphylaxis'*

Life threatening allergic reaction, usually developing within minutes of exposure to something the child is allergic to.  Various presentations, but may present with swelling of lips, mouth, throat, difficulty breathing, dizziness, loss of consciousness, abdominal pain or vomiting, and usually with a rash.

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis ALL of the following:
- Impetigo lesions seen
- Fever, or area of skin affected more than or equal to the size of 1 of the patient's palms

Impetigo is a bacterial skin infection, with pustules and sores with yellowish crusting. It usually occurs on the face or hands, but can also affect the body.

- Cough duration more than 2 weeks
- Neck mass persisting more than 4 weeks

*Consider scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

(adapted from IMCI 2014, based on studies from Kallander et al. PLoS Med, 2018; and Mullany et al. PLoS Med, 2018)

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis ALL of the following:
- Impetigo lesions seen
- Area of skin affected less than the size of 1 of the patient's palms
- No fever

Impetigo is a bacterial skin infection, with pustules and sores with yellowish crusting. It usually occurs on the face or hands, but can also affect the body.

description.en: On demand, max four times a day (roughly every 6hrs) as needed for pain or fever

"The child may be eating much less, or eating different foods during illness. Children often lose their appetite during illness. However, they should still be encouraged to eat the types of food recommended for their age, as often as recommended, even if they do not eat much. They should be offered their favourite nutritious foods, if possible, to encourage eating. Offer small feedings frequently. After illness, good feeding helps make up for any weight loss and prevent malnutrition.

During illness an infant or young child loses fluid due to fever, fast breathing, or diarrhoea. The child will feel better and stay stronger if he or she drinks extra fluid to prevent dehydration. Frequent breastfeeding will give the infant nourishment and help prevent dehydration. (IMCI Handbook)"

description.en:
The diagnosis of the patient does not require antibiotics because it is very likely not bacterial and/or often resolves without any medication. Antibiotics are not useful for viral infections, they are only useful for bacterial infections.

Giving an antibiotic for a viral illness or any illness not caused by bacteria is not good for the patient and may make the child more sick due to adverse effects of the antibiotics (diarrhea, rash, upset stomach). In the long run if children are exposed to antibiotics too many times when not needed, antibiotic resistance may develop. This means that antibiotics may not work when they are really needed. 
Reassure the patient and caretaker that antibiotics are not needed, and remind them of when to return to consultation if the child presents new symptoms, or does not get better.

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis:
- Current measles (generalised rash in a child with either cough, runny nose or red eyes) 
AND at least one of the following:
- Clouding of the cornea
- Deep or extensive mouth ulcers
- Danger sign
- Respiratory distress (including hypoxaemia)
- Chest indrawing pneumonia
- Severe acute malnutrition
- Very low weight for age
- HIV
- Known sickle cell disease
- Severe anaemia

description.en: Pre-referral Ampicillin IM
Pre-referral ceftriaxone IV/IM
Pre-referral Gentamicin
On demand, max four times a day (roughly every 6hrs) as needed for pain or fever

Give first dose now
Second dose tomorrow
If clouding of the cornea, give a third dose in 14 days time

Powder reconstituted to 0.25% with water

"For mouth ulcers: Treating mouth ulcers controls infection and helps the child to eat. Teach the mother to treat mouth ulcers with half-strength gentian violet. Gentian violet used in the mouth should be half-strength (0.25%), not full-strength (0.5%). Give the following information. 

Tell the mother:

• Her child will start eating normally sooner if she paints the mouth ulcers in her child’s mouth. It is important that the child eats. 
• Clean the child’s mouth. Wrap a clean soft cloth around her finger. Dip it in salt water. Wipe the mouth.
 • Use a clean cloth or a cotton-tipped stick to paint gentian violet on the mouth ulcers. The gentian violet will kill germs that cause the ulcers. Put a small amount of gentian violet on the cloth or stick. Do not let the child drink the gentian violet.
 • Treat the mouth ulcers 2 times per day, in the morning and evening.
 • Treat the mouth ulcers for 5 days and then stop.

Wrap a clean cloth around your finger and dip it into salt water. Show the mother how to first wipe the child’s mouth clean. Then paint half of the child’s mouth with halfstrength gentian violet.

Ask the mother to practise. Watch her wipe the child’s mouth clean and paint the rest of the ulcers with gentian violet. Comment on the steps she did well and those that need to be improved. Give the mother a bottle of half-strength gentian
 violet to take home. Tell her to return to the clinic if the mouth ulcers get worse or if the child is not able to drink or eat.
Before the mother leaves, ask checking questions. 
For example, ask:

“What will you use to clean the child’s mouth?”
“When will you wash your hands?”
“How often will you treat the child’s mouth?” “For how many days?”
If she anticipates any problems providing the treatment, help her to solve them."

Give first dose now
Second dose tomorrow
If clouding of the cornea, give a third dose in 14 days time
Vitamins - Dosage based on Age: <6 months : 50 000 IU

Give first dose now
Second dose tomorrow
If clouding of the cornea, give a third dose in 14 days time
6-12 months = 100,000 IU

description.en: Chickenpox is a very contagious viral disease, almost always resolves on it's own. Antibiotics are not useful for chicken pox. Remember prescribing antibiotics when it is not necessary can actually do more harm than good (side-effects of antibiotics, allergic reactions, antibiotic resistance).

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis:
- Genital problem AND 
- Scrotal pain or testicular tenderness

Testicular torsion occurs when a testicle rotates and twists the spermatic cord, which Causes sudden pain,swelling and high riding position of the testicle. Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency. Delay of surgical detorsion can result in testicular infarction in 6-12 hours.

description.en:
Duration : Pre-referral
- Weight based dosage 80mg/Kg/day (min dose per kg/day 60; max dose per kg/day 80); max daily dose: 4000mg
- Four times a day (roughly every 6hrs) as needed 
for pain or fever	
Oral	Tablet	500mg; breakable by 2

-	Manual detorsion is always from the medial to the lateral side (“opening a book”) 
-	May need to rotate 2-3 times for complete detorsion 
-	If the manoeuvre is successful, the patient feels a dramatic resolution of pain 
-	Refer after manual detorsion

description.en:
Refer to referral/district hospital or health center for surgical management. 

If distal forearm fracture in child under 5 years old, referral may not be needed.

If clavicular fracture:
Put a broad arm sling to support the limb for 2 weeks and:
-        Encourage the child to use hand and fingers
-        Avoid sports for 6 weeks especially contact sports
-        A lump at the fracture site is normal and may take about a year to disappear. In older children, a small bump may remain 

Advise to return to clinic if:
-        There is pain at the site of fracture after 6 weeks
-        There is a persistent tingling or altered sensation in the arm or hand

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis - ALL OF THE FOLLOWING
- Cough or difficulty breathing
- Chest indrawing or fast breathing* with no signs of severe pneumonia, PLUS any one of the following:
- No wheeze, or wheeze and no improvement after bronchodilator

*Fast breathing:
40 breaths per minute or more in a child 12 months or older 
50 breaths per minute or more in a child 2 to 11 months old

Pneumonia is an infection of one or both of the lungs. In children, it is commonly caused viruses, but sometimes caused by a bacteria. With the infection, small airways become swollen and produce more mucus. This can reduce the amount of oxygen that goes to the body. Pneumonia can appear after an upper respiratory tract infection. The symptoms include fever, cough and fast/difficult breathing, sometimes chest pain or abdominal pain. 
Bacterial pneumonia is treated with antibiotics. The child may continue to cough for up to 3 weeks after treatment, this can be normal if the child is otherwise getting better. "

Criteria for diagnosis = all of the following:
- Cough or difficulty breathing or runny nose
- No danger signs, signs of severe pneumonia, pneumonia, or other severe illnesses

Coughs and colds (upper respiratory tract infections) are very common in children.

description.en:
For Pain or fever
- Weight based dosing: 80mg/Kg/day (40-100 mg/Kg/day); max daily dose: 4000mg

-           Soothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy, such as tea with lemon, lime, or honey.
-       Drink fluids: Fluids keep the throat moist and prevent dehydration.
-       Clear secretions from child using a cloth soaked in water that has been twisted to form a pointed wick
(Adapted from IMCI 2014, and Mayo Clinic 2020)
description.sw:
-           Soothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy, such as tea with lemon, lime, or honey.
-       Drink fluids: Fluids keep the throat moist and prevent dehydration.
-       Clear secretions from child using a cloth soaked in water that has been twisted to form a pointed wick
(Adapted from IMCI 2014, and Mayo Clinic 2020)

description.en:
"The child may be eating much less, or eating different foods during illness. Children often lose their appetite during illness. However, they should still be encouraged to eat the types of food recommended for their age, as often as recommended, even if they do not eat much. They should be offered their favourite nutritious foods, if possible, to encourage eating. Offer small feedings frequently. After illness, good feeding helps make up for any weight loss and prevent malnutrition.

During illness an infant or young child loses fluid due to fever, fast breathing, or diarrhoea. The child will feel better and stay stronger if he or she drinks extra fluid to prevent dehydration. Frequent breastfeeding will give the infant nourishment and help prevent dehydration. (IMCI Handbook)"

description.en:
No inpatient referral is needed.
The patient may however need an outpatient referral for another diagnosis.

Advise the caretaker to bring back the child if the child presents: 
- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)
- Cough duration more than 2 weeks
- Neck mass persisting more than 4 weeks

*Consider scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

(adapted from IMCI 2014, based on studies from Kallander et al. PLoS Med, 2018; and Mullany et al. PLoS Med, 2018)

description.en:
The diagnosis of the patient does not require antibiotics because it is very likely not bacterial and/or often resolves without any medication. Antibiotics are not useful for viral infections, they are only useful for bacterial infections.

Giving an antibiotic for a viral illness or any illness not caused by bacteria is not good for the patient and may make the child more sick due to adverse effects of the antibiotics (diarrhea, rash, upset stomach). In the long run if children are exposed to antibiotics too many times when not needed, antibiotic resistance may develop. This means that antibiotics may not work when they are really needed. 
Reassure the patient and caretaker that antibiotics are not needed, and remind them of when to return to consultation if the child presents new symptoms, or does not get better.

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis:
- Loss of appetite
- No malnutrition / no severe infection

Loss of appetite is common in children, especially when they are sick. Re-assure the caretakers, and provide feeding counseling.

description.en:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants. Look for signs of hunger, such as beginning to fuss, sucking fingers, or moving lips.
- Breastfeed day and night whenever your baby wants, at least 8 times in 24 hours. Frequent feeding produces more milk.
- Do not give other foods or fluids. Breast milk is all your baby needs.
description.sw:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants. Look for signs of hunger, such as beginning to fuss, sucking fingers, or moving lips.
- Breastfeed day and night whenever your baby wants, at least 8 times in 24 hours. Frequent feeding produces more milk.
- Do not give other foods or fluids. Breast milk is all your baby needs.

description.en:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give a variety of mashed or finely chopped family food, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
-Give 3/4 cup at each meal (1 cup = 250 ml).
- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals.
- Continue to feed your child slowly, patiently. Encourage - but do not force - your child to eat.
- For snacks, give small chewable items that the child can hold. Let your child try to eat the snack, but provide help if needed.

description.en:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give thick porridge or well mashed foods, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
- Start by giving 2 to 3 tablespoons of food. Gradually increase to 1/2 cups (1 cup = 250 ml). Give 2 to 3 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks each day between meals when the child seems hungry.
description.sw:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give thick porridge or well mashed foods, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
- Start by giving 2 to 3 tablespoons of food. Gradually increase to 1/2 cups (1 cup = 250 ml). Give 2 to 3 meals each day.

description.en:
- Give a variety of family foods to your child, including animal source foods and vitamin rich fruits and vegetables.
- Give at least 1 full cup (250 ml) at each meal.
- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals.
- If your child refuses a new food, offer "tastes" several times. Show that you like the food.
Be patient.
- Talk with your child during a meal, and keep eye contact.

description.en:
Diagnostic criteria (all of following must be present):
- Neck mass(es) / lump(s)
- Onset less than 4 weeks ago
- Size under 3cm (of largest one if more than one present)
- No tenderness of neck mass(es)

Enlargement of cervical lymph node(s), mostly reactive after a viral infection and without signs of local inflammation (redness, tenderness). The small lymph nodes should spontaneously reduce in size over time. If they persist for more than 4 weeks or become large (individual lymph node / mass larger than 3cm) the child should be referred for specialist evaluation.
description.sw: Enlargement of cervical lymph node(s), mostly reactive after a viral infection and without signs of local inflammation (redness, tenderness). The size is not bigger than a plum and it does not increase over time but decrease in size spontaneously in most of the cases.

description.en: On demand, max four times a day (roughly every 6hrs) as needed for pain or fever

No inpatient referral is needed.
The patient may however need an outpatient referral for another diagnosis.

- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)
- Cough duration more than 2 weeks
- Neck mass persisting more than 4 weeks

*Consider scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

description.en:
Diagnostic criteria:
- Neck mass(es) / lump(s)
- Onset less than 4 weeks ago
- Size under 3cm (of largest one if more than one present)
- Tenderness of neck mass(es) present on palpation

Acute inflammation and infection of the cervical lymph nodes by pyogenic pathogens, usually unilateral. These should improve with antibiotics. If they do not improve with antibiotics (still painful / tender) or persist for more than 4 weeks or become large (individual lymph node / mass larger than 3cm) the child should be referred for specialist evaluation.
description.sw: Acute inflammation and infection of the cervical lymph nodes by pyogenic pathogens, usually unilateral.

description.en:
Antibiotic for skin infection
Dosing based on combined formulation 100-200mg/kg/day (equivalent to 50-100mg/kg/day for ampicilllin or cloxacillin separately)
On demand, max four times a day (roughly every 6hrs) as needed for pain or fever

No inpatient referral is needed.
The patient may however need an outpatient referral for another diagnosis.

- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)

description.en:
Diagnostic criteria:
- 1 or more neck mass / lump or lymph node
- Onset 4 weeks ago or longer, and / or size (of largest lump) larger than 3cm

Neck masses or lymph nodes present that are large or persistent can indicate tuberculosis, other complicated infections or tumours and must be investigated. If the child appears otherwise well, consider withholding antibiotics before TB testing. If child unwell, urgent or semi-urgent referral my be warranted.

description.en: Pre-referral treatment : Give the first dose of the medication before referring the child. The full duration of the treatment will be prescribed at the referral health facility.

Antibiotic for skin infection
Dosing based on combined formulation 100-200mg/kg/day (equivalent to 50-100mg/kg/day for ampicilllin or cloxacillin separately)

TB, tumor, or other complicated infection must be investigated.

Refer to referral/district hospital for specialized outpatient investigation. 

If child is well appearing / stable, consider withholding antibiotics before TB investigation.

If child unwell, semi-urgent referral my be warranted.

description.en: If the patient is stable and does not have any other severe disease diagnoses, refrain from giving antibiotics until TB assessment has been performed.

description.en: Refer with recommendation to go immediatly to referral health facility. Write a referral note for the caregiver to take to the hospital.

description.en: Breastfeed (if able), give 20-50 mL expressed breast milk, or give 20-50 mL sugar water; if unable to take PO, give 20-50 mL expressed breast milk or sugar water via NG tube. Sugar water: Dissolve 4 teaspoons (20 g) of sugar in 200 mL cup of clean water
description.sw: Breastfeed (if able), give 20-50 mL expressed breast milk, or give 20-50 mL sugar water; if unable to take PO, give 20-50 mL expressed breast milk or sugar water via NG tube. Sugar water: Dissolve 4 teaspoons (20 g) of sugar in 200 mL cup of clean water

description.en: Advise the mother how to keep the infant warm: Hold the infant in skin-to-skin contact. OR Keep the young infant clothed or covered as much as possible all the time, especially in cold weather. Add extra clothing, including hat, gloves and socks. Wrap the infant in a soft, dry cloth, and cover with a  blanket.

description.en: Council the mother on when to return immediately to the clinic: brastfeeding poorly; reduced activity; becomes sicker; develops a fever; feels unusually cold; develops fast breathing; develops difficulty breathing; palms or soles appear yellow
description.sw: Council the mother on when to return immediately to the clinic: brastfeeding poorly; reduced activity; becomes sicker; develops a fever; feels unusually cold; develops fast breathing; develops difficulty breathing; palms or soles appear yellow

description.en:
Immediately after birth, put your baby in skin-to-skin contact with you. 
• Allow your baby to take the breast within the first hour. Give your baby colostrum, the first yellowish, thick milk. It protects the baby from many Illnesses. 
• Breastfeed day and night, as often as your baby wants, at least 8 times in 24 hours. Frequent feeding produces more milk. 
• If your baby is small (low birth weight), feed him or her at least every 2 to 3 hours. Wake the baby for feeding after 3 hours, if she or he does not wake. 
• DO NOT give other foods or fluids. Breast milk is all your baby needs. This is especially important for infants of HIV-positive mothers. Mixed feeding increases the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV over that with breastfeeding.
• Continue to breastfeed even if the child is ill
(Source IMCI for sick young infants < 2 months of life, 2019)

description.en:
- Advise the mother on when to return immediately [see when to return immediately]. 
- Advise the mother to exclusively breastfeed the young infant, and to breastfeed frequently, as often and for as long as the infant wants, day and night, when sick and healthy. 
- Make sure that the infant is kept warm at all times. In cool weather, cover the infant's head and feet and add extra clothing.

description.en:
If major bleeding use simple dressings with direct pressure to control the bleeding.

In patients with major limb trauma use a tourniquet (a tight bandage/wrap that is placed proximal to the site of trauma (closer to the body) if direct pressure has failed to control life‑threatening bleeding.
(REF: NICE guidelines)

description.en:
If neck trauma or possible cervical spine injury stabilize neck, and keep the child lying on the back.
Tape the child's forehead and chin to the sides of a firm board to secure this position.
Prevent the neck from moving by supporting the child's head (e.g. using litre bags of IV fluid on each side).
If the child is vomiting, turn on the side, keeping the head in line with the body.

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis - 
- Abdominal pain and less frequent and hard stools

Constipation is a very common condition in children. In most of cases, no cause is discovered. Low fiber intake may be associated. It is often difficult to treat and requires therefore prolonged support.
description.sw:
Criteria for diagnosis - 
- Abdominal pain and less frequent and hard stools

Constipation is a very common condition in children. In most of cases, no cause is discovered. Low fiber intake may be associated. It is often difficult to treat and requires therefore prolonged support.

description.en:
"-    The goal is achieving one, soft, easy to pass bowel action per day (exception: breastfed babies who are otherwise well may defecate infrequently (several times a day to one a week)  
-     Treatment is usually required for several months:
-      Encourage to eat fruits/vegetables
-      Eating only ugali or rice may worsen constipation, diversify types of food if possible
-      Avoid rectal medication or manipulation 

If constipation counselling is not sufficient for children >= 3 years a trial of bisacodyl 5mg tablets once daily may help."

description.en:
No inpatient referral is needed.
The patient may however need an outpatient referral for another diagnosis.

Advise the caretaker to bring back the child if the child presents: 
- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)
- Cough duration more than 2 weeks
- Neck mass persisting more than 4 weeks

*Consider scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

(adapted from IMCI 2014, based on studies from Kallander et al. PLoS Med, 2018; and Mullany et al. PLoS Med, 2018)

description.en: Apply to dry hair for 8 to 12 hours before washing off with a nonmedicated shampoo. The hair should be left uncovered, and heat sources should not be used to dry the hair. Perform second application 1 week apart.

description.en:
-	In the case of scabies: Treat whole family and close contacts simultaneously regardless of presence of absence of itching 
-	Moisture the skin with hydrating cream daily after initial treatment 
-	In the case of head lice: treat family members if infested (examine each household member)
-	Advise patients to bathe and dress in clean clothing
-	Boil clothes and bed linen for 10 minutes followed by ironing; soaking brushes, combs and hair ornaments in hot water for 10 minutes. 
-	any  bedding, clothing, or towels that cannot be washed should be placed in a sealed plastic bag for at least 3 days.

description.en:
Diagnostic criteria:
- Cellulitis seen on examination AND ONE OR MORE OF THE FOLLOWING:
- Danger sign
- Cellulitis on face
- Severe pain (of affected area of skin)
- Large (size 2 or more of patient's palm)
- No improvement after 3 days of antibiotics 

A serious form of cellulitis (bacterial skin infection) that may need IV antibiotic treatment. Refer or admit the child for surveillance and parenteral treatment.
description.sw: A serious form of cellulitis (bacterial skin infection) that may need IV antibiotic treatment. Refer or admit the child for surveillance and parenteral treatment.

description.en: Antibiotic: 50 mg/Kg/day, max 2g/day
Antibiotic for skin infection
On demand, max four times a day (roughly every 6hrs) as needed for pain or fever

"The child may be eating much less, or eating different foods during illness. Children often lose their appetite during illness. However, they should still be encouraged to eat the types of food recommended for their age, as often as recommended, even if they do not eat much. They should be offered their favourite nutritious foods, if possible, to encourage eating. Offer small feedings frequently. After illness, good feeding helps make up for any weight loss and prevent malnutrition.

During illness an infant or young child loses fluid due to fever, fast breathing, or diarrhoea. The child will feel better and stay stronger if he or she drinks extra fluid to prevent dehydration. Frequent breastfeeding will give the infant nourishment and help prevent dehydration. (IMCI Handbook)"

description.en:
-	Many viruses cause a maculo-papular rash, they can be accompanied with nonspecific symptoms such as fever, headache, muscle, joint or back pain.
-	Differential diagnosis include: Erythema infectiosum, Roseola infantum, Infectious mononucleosis, dengue, chikungunya, Zika
- A definitive diagnosis requires laboratory tests that are often not available outside of hospitals, so the diagnosis is usually presumptive.
- Treatment is usually supportive, antibiotics are not useful for viral diseases

**If the diagnosis is not clear, return to the complaint categories to select "Fever without source" (if not already selected)

description.en:
Chronic limp or joint pain 2 weeks or longer. 
Chronic limp or joint pain can be caused by a rheumatic disease (juvenile idiopathic arthritis), Perthes disease (avascular necrosis of the femoral head), tuberculous arthritis, malignant disease or trauma. If the symptoms are persisting with no improvement further investigations may be necessary.

description.en: On demand, max four times a day (roughly every 6hrs) as needed for pain or fever

Refer to referral/district hospital for specialized outpatient investigations and management by health care workers with advanced capacity to manage chronic limp, or chronic joint pain, or severe deep tissue injury, or suspected/confirmed fracture.
description.sw: Refer to referral/district hospital for specialized outpatient investigations and management by health care workers with advanced capacity to manage chronic limp, or chronic joint pain, or severe deep tissue injury, or suspected/confirmed fracture.

description.en: Duration of symtoms: less than 2 weeks. In the pre-school age group, a transient synovitis of the hip is one of the commonest reasons for a limp. These children usually have a history of recent viral upper respiratory tract infection, are usually able to walk, but with pain, and are otherwise well and afebrile. Other common diagnoses include Toddlers fracture (< 4 years; spiral and undisplaced fracture of tibia that heals spontaneously) and contusion.

description.en:
Diagnostic criteria - ALL OF THE FOLLOWING:
- Pain or swelling of a joint or bone
- Fever, known HIV or known sickle cell disease
- Warm, tender or swollen joint

Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone. Septic arthritis is an infection of a synovial joint. Both infections are usually caused by spread of a bacteria through the blood. Antibiotics are the treatment of choice. Untreated, it can sometimes result in irreversible bone/ joint damage, sepsis and even death.
description.sw:
Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone. Septic arthritis is an infection of a synovial joint. Both infections are usually caused by spread of a bacteria (S. aureus in older children, K. kingae, H. influenzae type b, S. pneumoniae or S. pyogenes in younger children) through the blood. Antibiotics is the treatment of choice. Untreated, it can sometimes result in irreversible bone/ joint damage, sepsis and even death.  

Diagnosis of osteomyelitis and septic arthritis is complicated. Elevated CRP may help distinguish ostemoyelitis and septic arthritis from less severe acute limp or joint pain, and those needing antibiotics.

description.en:
-	Tell the mother to give extra fluid 
-	Breastfeed frequently and for longer at each feed
-	If the child is exclusively breastfed, give ORS or clean water in addition to breast milk 
-	If the child is not exclusively breastfed, give one or more of the following: ORS Solution, food-based fluids (such as soup, rice water, yoghurt drinks) or clean water
-	when the child cannot return to a clinic if the diarrhea gets worse, it is especially important to give ORS at home 
-	Give the mother at least 2 packets of ORS to use at home
-	Give additional fluid

QUANTITY to give:
-	2m-2y: 50-100ml after each loose stool
-	> 2y: 100-200ml after each loose stool

-	Give frequent small sips from a cup (or a spoon)
-	If the child vomits, wait 10 min. Then continue, but more slowly
-	Continue giving extra fluid until diarrhea stops 
-	Continue feeding (exclusive breastfeeding if age less than 6 months)
REF IMCI 2014

Click on photo below for IMCI guidance

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis - BOTH OF:
- Diarrhoea (loose or liquid stool) - any number of episodes
- Blood in stool

Dysentery is bloody diarrhoea, i.e. any diarrhoeal episode in which the loose or watery stools contain visible red blood. Dysentery is most often caused by Shigella species (bacillary dysentery) or Entamoeba histolytica (amoebic dysentery). (WHO, 2020)

-	Give additional fluid

QUANTITY to give:
-	2m-2y: 50-100ml after each loose stool
-	> 2y: 100-200ml after each loose stool

-	Give frequent small sips from a cup (or a spoon)
-	If the child vomits, wait 10 min. Then continue, but more slowly
-	Continue giving extra fluid until diarrhea stops 
-	Continue feeding (exclusive breastfeeding if age less than 6 months)
REF IMCI 2014

description.en:
No inpatient referral is needed.
The patient may however need an outpatient referral for another diagnosis.

Advise the caretaker to bring back the child if the child presents: 
- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)
- Cough duration more than 2 weeks
- Neck mass persisting more than 4 weeks

*Consider scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

(adapted from IMCI 2014, based on studies from Kallander et al. PLoS Med, 2018; and Mullany et al. PLoS Med, 2018)

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis - EITHER: 
- Diarrhoea or vomiting with no signs of dehydration
- Abdominal pain and no severe signs

Non-severe gastrointestinal condition is common in children. Diagnosis is made after having excluded severe conditions that need further investigation.

Non-severe gastrointestinal condition is common in children. Diagnosis is made after having excluded severe conditions that need further investigation.

description.en: On demand, max four times a day (roughly every 6hrs) as needed for pain or fever

- Give a variety of family foods to your child, including animal source foods and vitamin rich fruits and vegetables.
- Give at least 1 full cup (250 ml) at each meal.
- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals.
- If your child refuses a new food, offer "tastes" several times. Show that you like the food.
Be patient.
- Talk with your child during a meal, and keep eye contact.

description.en:
The diagnosis of the patient does not require antibiotics because it is very likely not bacterial and/or often resolves without any medication. Antibiotics are not useful for viral infections, they are only useful for bacterial infections.

Giving an antibiotic for a viral illness or any illness not caused by bacteria is not good for the patient and may make the child more sick due to adverse effects of the antibiotics (diarrhea, rash, upset stomach). In the long run if children are exposed to antibiotics too many times when not needed, antibiotic resistance may develop. This means that antibiotics may not work when they are really needed. 
Reassure the patient and caretaker that antibiotics are not needed, and remind them of when to return to consultation if the child presents new symptoms, or does not get better.

description.en:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants. Look for signs of hunger, such as beginning to fuss, sucking fingers, or moving lips.
- Breastfeed day and night whenever your baby wants, at least 8 times in 24 hours. Frequent feeding produces more milk.
- Do not give other foods or fluids. Breast milk is all your baby needs.
description.sw:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants. Look for signs of hunger, such as beginning to fuss, sucking fingers, or moving lips.
- Breastfeed day and night whenever your baby wants, at least 8 times in 24 hours. Frequent feeding produces more milk.
- Do not give other foods or fluids. Breast milk is all your baby needs.

description.en:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give a variety of mashed or finely chopped family food, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
-Give 3/4 cup at each meal (1 cup = 250 ml).
- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals.
- Continue to feed your child slowly, patiently. Encourage - but do not force - your child to eat.
- For snacks, give small chewable items that the child can hold. Let your child try to eat the snack, but provide help if needed.

- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals.
- Continue to feed your child slowly, patiently. Encourage - but do not force - your child to eat.
- For snacks, give small chewable items that the child can hold. Let your child try to eat the snack, but provide help if needed.

description.en:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give thick porridge or well mashed foods, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
- Start by giving 2 to 3 tablespoons of food. Gradually increase to 1/2 cups (1 cup = 250 ml). Give 2 to 3 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks each day between meals when the child seems hungry.

description.en:
The infant may be presenting infantile colic. It is a condition that most often resolves with time. 
Review the feeding with the mother, and assure that the infant is not being underfed or overfed. Propose different soothing techniques including lightly rocking the infant, providing a warm bath, rubbing the infant's abdomen, or carrying the baby while walking.

description.en:
Criteria for diagnosis - BOTH OF THE FOLLOWING:
- Diarrhoea (3 or more loose or liquid stools per day) lasting less than 14 days
- NO dehydration

description.en:
Vitamins; Oral;
Capsule: 50,000 IU; 100,000 IU. 
Oral oily solution: 100,000 IU/mL. 
Tablet: 10,000 IU; 50,000 IU
Dosage based on Age: >= 1 years :200 000 IU	 1 time a day			
Do not give if the child is already on RUTF, or received vit A within the past month.

Vitamins; Oral; 
Capsule: 50,000 IU; 100,000 IU. 
Oral oily solution: 100,000 IU/mL. 
Tablet: 10,000 IU; 50,000 IU
Dosage based on Age: Age 6 - 12 months	100 000 IU 1 time a day	
Do not give if the child is less than 6 months, or is already on RUTF, or received vit A within the past month.

description.sw:
-	Tell the mother to give extra fluid 
-	Breastfeed frequently and for longer at each feed
-	If the child is exclusively breastfed, give ORS or clean water in addition to breast milk 
-	If the child is not exclusively breastfed, give one or more of the following: ORS Solution, food-based fluids (such as soup, rice water, yoghurt drinks) or clean water
-	when the child cannot return to a clinic if the diarrhea gets worse, it is especially important to give ORS at home 
-	Give the mother at least 2 packets of ORS to use at home
-	Give additional fluid

QUANTITY to give:
-	2m-2y: 50-100ml after each loose stool
-	> 2y: 100-200ml after each loose stool

-	Give frequent small sips from a cup (or a spoon)
-	If the child vomits, wait 10 min. Then continue, but more slowly
-	Continue giving extra fluid until diarrhea stops 
-	Continue feeding (exclusive breastfeeding if age less than 6 months)
REF IMCI 2014

Click on photo below for IMCI guidance

description.en:
The diagnosis of the patient does not require antibiotics because it is very likely not bacterial and/or often resolves without any medication. Antibiotics are not useful for viral infections, they are only useful for bacterial infections.

Giving an antibiotic for a viral illness or any illness not caused by bacteria is not good for the patient and may make the child more sick due to adverse effects of the antibiotics (diarrhea, rash, upset stomach). In the long run if children are exposed to antibiotics too many times when not needed, antibiotic resistance may develop. This means that antibiotics may not work when they are really needed. 
Reassure the patient and caretaker that antibiotics are not needed, and remind them of when to return to consultation if the child presents new symptoms, or does not get better.

description.en:
No inpatient referral is needed.
The patient may however need an outpatient referral for another diagnosis.

Advise the caretaker to bring back the child if the child presents: 
- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)
- Cough duration more than 2 weeks
- Neck mass persisting more than 4 weeks

*Consider scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

(adapted from IMCI 2014, based on studies from Kallander et al. PLoS Med, 2018; and Mullany et al. PLoS Med, 2018)

description.en:
Technique

– Settle the patient comfortably in an area with good lighting and ensure all the necessary material is prepared.
– Explain the procedure to the patient and ensure his co-operation.
– If the patient is a young child, arrange to have an assistant hold the child if necessary.
Initial cleaning

– Wear suitable clothing: sterile gloves for all wounds and a gown and protective glasses if there is a risk of projection from a bleeding wound.
– Start by washing the wound, prolong the cleaning if the wound is particularly soiled. Use ordinary soap or 7.5% povidone iodine scrub solution and water and rinse.
– If necessary use a sterile brush. Cleaning with running water is preferable to cleaning by immersion.
– If the wound is infected and the patient has general signs of infection (fever, chills, changes in the overall condition) systemic antibiotic therapy may be required. Administer antibiotics at least one hour prior to starting care.
Exploration

– Wash hands and put on sterile gloves.
– Disinfect the wound and surrounding area with 10% povidone iodine.
– Cover the wound with a fenestrated sterile towel.
– Local anaesthetic: infiltrate 1% lidocaine into the edges of the wound and wait at least 2 minutes for the anaesthetic to take effect.
– Proceed carefully from the superficial to the deepest parts of the wound to explore the extent of the wound, if necessary, aided by an assistant.
– Consider the anatomical location of the wound and look for injury to any underlying structures (the clinical examination of a limb must include evaluation of sensitivity and motor functioning, as well as that of tendons in order to orient surgical exploration):
• a wound that communicates with a fracture is an open fracture,
• a wound close to a joint may be a joint wound,
• a wound on the hands or feet may affect the nerves and/or tendons.
– Look for and remove any foreign bodies.
– In the event of significant pain or bleeding, the exploration must be completed in an operating room.
Wound excision

– The goal of the excision is to remove non-viable tissue, which favours the proliferation of bacteria and infection.
– The wound may require little or no excision if it is clean. The excision is more extensive if the wound is bruised, irregular or extensive.
– Limit excision of the skin around the wound, particularly in facial wounds.
– Sub-cutaneous fat and tissue of doubtful viability should be generously excised in order to leave only well vascularised tissue.

REF: MSF Clinical Guidelines

description.en: Refer urgently with caretaker for inpatient management at a health centre or hospital with sufficient capacity to manage the illness of the patient. If referral is not possible, manage the child as described in the national guidelines or WHO Pocket Book for hospital care for children.

description.en: Fungal infection of the skin of the scalp caused by dermatophytes. In some children, a massive host inflammatory response result in a kerion (boggy, localized mass, often peppered with pustules). Topical therapies are ineffective in tinea capitis. Oral griseofluvin is required for a minimum of 6-12 weeks, ideally given with fatty foods to improve its absorption.

description.en: Fungal skin disease caused by dermatophytes. Transmission is via close contact of infected skin epithelial cells deposited on surfaces such as chairs, hats, combs ect. or via animals.
description.sw: Fungal skin disease caused by dermatophytes. Transmission is via close contact of infected skin epithelial cells deposited on surfaces such as chairs, hats, combs ect. or via animals.

description.en: Fungal skin disease caused by dermatophytes. Transmission is via close contact of infected skin epithelial cells deposited on surfaces such as chairs, hats, combs ect. or via animals. Severe cases, often due to an immunecompromised status, can lead to generalized skin manifestation.
